column2: BALTIMORE, October 3. The president of the Gun Club has the honor to inform his colleagues that, at the meeting of the 5th instant, he will bring before them a communication of an extremely interesting nature.
column3: BALTIMORE, october third. The president of the Gun Club has the honor to inform his colleagues that, at the meeting of the fifth instant, he will bring before them a communication of an extremely interesting nature.

column2: He requests, therefore, that they will make it convenient to attend in accordance with the present invitation.
column3: He requests, therefore, that they will make it convenient to attend in accordance with the present invitation.

column2: Very cordially, IMPEY BARBICANE, P.G.C.
column3: Very cordially, IMPEY b a r b i c a n e, p g c

column2: CHAPTER II

column2: PRESIDENT BARBICANE'S COMMUNICATION
column3: PRESIDENT BARBICANE'S COMMUNICATION

column2: On the 5th of October, at eight p.m., a dense crowd pressed toward the saloons of the Gun Club at No. 21 Union Square. All the members of the association resident in Baltimore attended the invitation of their president.
column3: On the fifth of October, at eight p.m., a dense crowd pressed toward the saloons of the Gun Club at no twenty one Union Square. All the members of the association resident in Baltimore attended the invitation of their president.

column2: As regards the corresponding members, notices were delivered by hundreds throughout the streets of the city, and, large as was the great hall, it was quite inadequate to accommodate the crowd of _savants_.
column3: As regards the corresponding members, notices were delivered by hundreds throughout the streets of the city, and, large as was the great hall, it was quite inadequate to accommodate the crowd of underscore savants underscore.

column2: They overflowed into the adjoining rooms, down the narrow passages, into the outer courtyards.
column3: They overflowed into the adjoining rooms, down the narrow passages, into the outer courtyards.

column2: There they ran against the vulgar herd who pressed up to the doors, each struggling to reach the front ranks, all eager to learn the nature of the important communication of President Barbicane; all pushing, squeezing, crushing with that perfect freedom of action which is so peculiar to the masses when educated in ideas of "self-government."
column3: There they ran against the vulgar herd who pressed up to the doors, each struggling to reach the front ranks, all eager to learn the nature of the important communication of President Barbicane; all pushing, squeezing, crushing with that perfect freedom of action which is so peculiar to the masses when educated in ideas of "self government."

column2: On that evening a stranger who might have chanced to be in Baltimore could not have gained admission for love or money into the great hall.
column3: On that evening a stranger who might have chanced to be in Baltimore could not have gained admission for love or money into the great hall.

column2: That was reserved exclusively for resident or corresponding members; no one else could possibly have obtained a place; and the city magnates, municipal councilors, and "select men" were compelled to mingle with the mere townspeople in order to catch stray bits of news from the interior.

column2: Nevertheless the vast hall presented a curious spectacle. Its immense area was singularly adapted to the purpose. Lofty pillars formed of cannon, superposed upon huge mortars as a base, supported the fine ironwork of the arches, a perfect piece of cast-iron lacework.
column3: Nevertheless the vast hall presented a curious spectacle. Its immense area was singularly adapted to the purpose. Lofty pillars formed of cannon, superposed upon huge mortars as a base, supported the fine ironwork of the arches, a perfect piece of cast iron lacework.

column2: Trophies of blunderbuses, matchlocks, arquebuses, carbines, all kinds of firearms, ancient and modern, were picturesquely interlaced against the walls.
column3: Trophies of blunderbuses, matchlocks, arquebuses, carbines, all kinds of firearms, ancient and modern, were picturesquely interlaced against the walls.

column2: The gas lit up in full glare myriads of revolvers grouped in the form of lustres, while groups of pistols, and candelabra formed of muskets bound together, completed this magnificent display of brilliance.
column3: The gas lit up in full glare myriads of revolvers grouped in the form of lustres, while groups of pistols, and candelabra formed of muskets bound together, completed this magnificent display of brilliance.

column2: Models of cannon, bronze castings, sights covered with dents, plates battered by the shots of the Gun Club, assortments of rammers and sponges, chaplets of shells, wreaths of projectiles, garlands of howitzers-- in short, all the apparatus of the artillerist, enchanted the eye by this wonderful arrangement and induced a kind of belief that their real purpose was ornamental rather than deadly.

column2: At the further end of the saloon the president, assisted by four secretaries, occupied a large platform.
column3: At the further end of the saloon the president, assisted by four secretaries, occupied a large platform.

column2: His chair, supported by a carved gun-carriage, was modeled upon the ponderous proportions of a 32-inch mortar.
column3: His chair, supported by a carved gun carriage, was modeled upon the ponderous proportions of a thirty two-inch mortar.

column2: It was pointed at an angle of ninety degrees, and suspended upon truncheons, so that the president could balance himself upon it as upon a rocking-chair, a very agreeable fact in the very hot weather.
column3: It was pointed at an angle of ninety degrees, and suspended upon truncheons, so that the president could balance himself upon it as upon a rocking chair, a very agreeable fact in the very hot weather.

column2: Upon the table (a huge iron plate supported upon six carronades) stood an inkstand of exquisite elegance, made of a beautifully chased Spanish piece, and a sonnette, which, when required, could give forth a report equal to that of a revolver. During violent debates this novel kind of bell scarcely sufficed to drown the clamor of these excitable artillerists.

column2: In front of the table benches arranged in zigzag form, like the circumvallations of a retrenchment, formed a succession of bastions and curtains set apart for the use of the members of the club; and on this especial evening one might say, "All the world was on the ramparts." The president was sufficiently well known, however, for all to be assured that he would not put his colleagues to discomfort without some very strong motive.

column2: Impey Barbicane was a man of forty years of age, calm, cold, austere; of a singularly serious and self-contained demeanor, punctual as a chronometer, of imperturbable temper and immovable character; by no means chivalrous, yet adventurous withal, and always bringing practical ideas to bear upon the very rashest enterprises; an essentially New Englander, a Northern colonist, a descendant of the old anti-Stuart Roundheads, and the implacable enemy of the gentlemen of the South, those ancient cavaliers of the mother country.
column3: Impey Barbicane was a man of forty years of age, calm, cold, austere; of a singularly serious and self-contained demeanor, punctual as a chronometer, of imperturbable temper and immovable character; by no means chivalrous, yet adventurous withal, and always bringing practical ideas to bear upon the very rashest enterprises; an essentially New Englander, a Northern colonist, a descendant of the old anti Stuart Roundheads, and the implacable enemy of the gentlemen of the South, those ancient cavaliers of the mother country.

column2: In a word, he was a Yankee to the backbone.
column3: In a word, he was a Yankee to the backbone.

column2: Barbicane had made a large fortune as a timber merchant. Being nominated director of artillery during the war, he proved himself fertile in invention.
column3: Barbicane had made a large fortune as a timber merchant. Being nominated director of artillery during the war, he proved himself fertile in invention.

column2: Bold in his conceptions, he contributed powerfully to the progress of that arm and gave an immense impetus to experimental researches.
column3: Bold in his conceptions, he contributed powerfully to the progress of that arm and gave an immense impetus to experimental researches.

column2: He was personage of the middle height, having, by a rare exception in the Gun Club, all his limbs complete.
column3: He was personage of the middle height, having, by a rare exception in the Gun Club, all his limbs complete.

column2: His strongly marked features seemed drawn by square and rule; and if it be true that, in order to judge a man's character one must look at his profile, Barbicane, so examined, exhibited the most certain indications of energy, audacity, and _sang-froid_.
column3: His strongly marked features seemed drawn by square and rule; and if it be true that, in order to judge a man's character one must look at his profile, Barbicane, so examined, exhibited the most certain indications of energy, audacity, and underscore sang froid underscore.

column2: At this moment he was sitting in his armchair, silent, absorbed, lost in reflection, sheltered under his high-crowned hat-- a kind of black cylinder which always seems firmly screwed upon the head of an American.
column3: At this moment he was sitting in his armchair, silent, absorbed, lost in reflection, sheltered under his high crowned hat- a kind of black cylinder which always seems firmly screwed upon the head of an American.

column2: Just when the deep-toned clock in the great hall struck eight, Barbicane, as if he had been set in motion by a spring, raised himself up.
column3: Just when the deep toned clock in the great hall struck eight, Barbicane, as if he had been set in motion by a spring, raised himself up.

column2: A profound silence ensued, and the speaker, in a somewhat emphatic tone of voice, commenced as follows:
column3: A profound silence ensued, and the speaker, in a somewhat emphatic tone of voice, commenced as follows:

column2: My brave, colleagues, too long already a paralyzing peace has plunged the members of the Gun Club in deplorable inactivity. After a period of years full of incidents we have been compelled to abandon our labors, and to stop short on the road of progress. I do not hesitate to state, baldly, that any war which would recall us to arms would be welcome! (Tremendous applause!) "But war, gentlemen, is impossible under existing circumstances; and, however we may desire it, many years may elapse before our cannon shall again thunder in the field of battle.
column3: My brave, colleagues, too long already a paralyzing peace has plunged the members of the Gun Club in deplorable inactivity. After a period of years full of incidents we have been compelled to abandon our labors, and to stop short on the road of progress. I do not hesitate to state, baldly, that any war which would recall us to arms would be welcome! (Tremendous applause!) "But war, gentlemen, is impossible under existing circumstances; and, however we may desire it, many years may elapse before our cannon shall again thunder in the field of battle.

column2: We must make up our minds, then, to seek in another train of ideas some field for the activity which we all pine for."
column3: We must make up our minds, then, to seek in another train of ideas some field for the activity which we all pine for."

column2: The meeting felt that the president was now approaching the critical point, and redoubled their attention accordingly.
column3: The meeting felt that the president was now approaching the critical point, and redoubled their attention accordingly.

column2: For some months past, my brave colleagues, continued Barbicane, "I have been asking myself whether, while confining ourselves to our own particular objects, we could not enter upon some grand experiment worthy of the nineteenth century; and whether the progress of artillery science would not enable us to carry it out to a successful issue.
column3: For some months past, my brave colleagues, continued Barbicane, "I have been asking myself whether, while confining ourselves to our own particular objects, we could not enter upon some grand experiment worthy of the nineteenth century; and whether the progress of artillery science would not enable us to carry it out to a successful issue.

column2: I have been considering, working, calculating; and the result of my studies is the conviction that we are safe to succeed in an enterprise which to any other country would appear wholly impracticable.
column3: I have been considering, working, calculating; and the result of my studies is the conviction that we are safe to succeed in an enterprise which to any other country would appear wholly impracticable.

column2: This project, the result of long elaboration, is the object of my present communication. It is worthy of yourselves, worthy of the antecedents of the Gun Club; and it cannot fail to make some noise in the world."
column3: This project, the result of long elaboration, is the object of my present communication. It is worthy of yourselves, worthy of the antecedents of the Gun Club; and it cannot fail to make some noise in the world."

column2: A thrill of excitement ran through the meeting.
column3: A thrill of excitement ran through the meeting.

column2: Barbicane, having by a rapid movement firmly fixed his hat upon his head, calmly continued his harangue:
column3: Barbicane, having by a rapid movement firmly fixed his hat upon his head, calmly continued his harangue:

column2: There is no one among you, my brave colleagues, who has not seen the Moon, or, at least, heard speak of it.	There is no one among you, my brave colleagues, who has not seen the Moon, or, at least, heard speak of it.

column2: Don't be surprised if I am about to discourse to you regarding the Queen of the Night.
column3: Don't be surprised if I am about to discourse to you regarding the Queen of the Night.

column2: It is perhaps reserved for us to become the Columbuses of this unknown world.
column3: It is perhaps reserved for us to become the Columbuses of this unknown world.

column2: Only enter into my plans, and second me with all your power, and I will lead you to its conquest, and its name shall be added to those of the thirty-six states which compose this Great Union."
column3: Only enter into my plans, and second me with all your power, and I will lead you to its conquest, and its name shall be added to those of the thirty six states which compose this Great Union."

column2: Three cheers for the Moon! roared the Gun Club, with one voice.
column3: Three cheers for the Moon! roared the Gun Club, with one voice.

column2: The moon, gentlemen, has been carefully studied, continued Barbicane; "her mass, density, and weight; her constitution, motions, distance, as well as her place in the solar system, have all been exactly determined.
column3: The moon, gentlemen, has been carefully studied, continued Barbicane; "her mass, density, and weight; her constitution, motions, distance, as well as her place in the solar system, have all been exactly determined.

column2: Selenographic charts have been constructed with a perfection which equals, if it does not even surpass, that of our terrestrial maps.
column3: Selenographic charts have been constructed with a perfection which equals, if it does not even surpass, that of our terrestrial maps.

column2: Photography has given us proofs of the incomparable beauty of our satellite; all is known regarding the moon which mathematical science, astronomy, geology, and optics can learn about her.
column3: Photography has given us proofs of the incomparable beauty of our satellite; all is known regarding the moon which mathematical science, astronomy, geology, and optics can learn about her.

column2: But up to the present moment no direct communication has been established with her."
column3: But up to the present moment no direct communication has been established with her."

column2: A violent movement of interest and surprise here greeted this remark of the speaker.
column3: A violent movement of interest and surprise here greeted this remark of the speaker.

column2: Permit me, he continued, "to recount to you briefly how certain ardent spirits, starting on imaginary journeys, have penetrated the secrets of our satellite.
column3: Permit me, he continued, "to recount to you briefly how certain ardent spirits, starting on imaginary journeys, have penetrated the secrets of our satellite.

column2: In the seventeenth century a certain David Fabricius boasted of having seen with his own eyes the inhabitants of the moon.
column3: In the seventeenth century a certain David Fabricius boasted of having seen with his own eyes the inhabitants of the moon.

column2: In 1649 a Frenchman, one Jean Baudoin, published a `Journey performed from the Earth to the Moon by Domingo Gonzalez,' a Spanish adventurer.

column2: But, to bring this rapid sketch to a close, I will only add that a certain Hans Pfaal, of Rotterdam, launching himself in a balloon filled with a gas extracted from nitrogen, thirty-seven times lighter than hydrogen, reached the moon after a passage of nineteen hours.

column2: This journey, like all previous ones, was purely imaginary; still, it was the work of a popular American author-- I mean Edgar Poe!"

column2: I have now enumerated, said Barbicane, "the experiments which I call purely paper ones, and wholly insufficient to establish serious relations with the Queen of the Night.
column3: I have now enumerated, said Barbicane, "the experiments which I call purely paper ones, and wholly insufficient to establish serious relations with the Queen of the Night.

column2: Nevertheless, I am bound to add that some practical geniuses have attempted to establish actual communication with her.
column3: Nevertheless, I am bound to add that some practical geniuses have attempted to establish actual communication with her.

column2: Thus, a few days ago, a German geometrician proposed to send a scientific expedition to the steppes of Siberia.
column3: Thus, a few days ago, a German geometrician proposed to send a scientific expedition to the steppes of Siberia.

column2: There, on those vast plains, they were to describe enormous geometric figures, drawn in characters of reflecting luminosity, among which was the proposition regarding the `square of the hypothenuse,' commonly called the `Ass's Bridge' by the French.

column2: `Every intelligent being,' said the geometrician, `must understand the scientific meaning of that figure.

column2: The Selenites, do they exist, will respond by a similar figure; and, a communication being thus once established, it will be easy to form an alphabet which shall enable us to converse with the inhabitants of the moon.' column2: It is reserved for the practical genius of Americans to establish a communication with the sidereal world.

column2: The means of arriving thither are simple, easy, certain, infallible-- and that is the purpose of my present proposal."

column2: A storm of acclamations greeted these words.

column2: There was not a single person in the whole audience who was not overcome, carried away, lifted out of himself by the speaker's words!

column2: Long-continued applause resounded from all sides.

column2: As soon as the excitement had partially subsided, Barbicane resumed his speech in a somewhat graver voice.
column3: As soon as the excitement had partially subsided, Barbicane resumed his speech in a somewhat graver voice.

column2: You know, said he, "what progress artillery science has made during the last few years, and what a degree of perfection firearms of every kind have reached.
column3: You know, said he, "what progress artillery science has made during the last few years, and what a degree of perfection firearms of every kind have reached.

column2: Moreover, you are well aware that, in general terms, the resisting power of cannon and the expansive force of gunpowder are practically unlimited. Well! starting from this principle, I ask myself whether, supposing sufficient apparatus could be obtained constructed upon the conditions of ascertained resistance, it might not be possible to project a shot up to the moon?"
column3: Moreover, you are well aware that, in general terms, the resisting power of cannon and the expansive force of gunpowder are practically unlimited. column2: At these words a murmur of amazement escaped from a thousand panting chests; then succeeded a moment of perfect silence, resembling that profound stillness which precedes the bursting of a thunderstorm.
column3: At these words a murmur of amazement escaped from a thousand panting chests; then succeeded a moment of perfect silence, resembling that profound stillness which precedes the bursting of a thunderstorm.

column2: In point of fact, a thunderstorm did peal forth, but it was the thunder of applause, or cries, and of uproar which made the very hall tremble.
column3: In point of fact, a thunderstorm did peal forth, but it was the thunder of applause, or cries, and of uproar which made the very hall tremble.

column2: It was fully ten minutes before he could make himself heard.

column2: Suffer me to finish, he calmly continued.

column2: I have looked at the question in all its bearings, I have resolutely attacked it, and by incontrovertible calculations I find that a projectile endowed with an initial velocity of 12,000 yards per second, and aimed at the moon, must necessarily reach it. column2: I have the honor, my brave colleagues, to propose a trial of this little experiment."
